<root><template><title>Command</title><part><name>Comments</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="1"/><value> ofpr </value></part><part><name>Game name</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>1.75</value></part><part><name>Game version</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>arg</name>=<value> global </value></part><part><name>Multiplayer Arguments</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>eff</name>=<value> global </value></part><part><name>Multiplayer Effects</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>gr1</name>=<value> Animations </value></part><part><name>GROUP1</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value> Activates given object animation. Animation is defined in CfgModels [[Model Config#Animations|animations]] class.<br>
Since <template><title>arma3</title></template> v1.58 animation names can be obtained with [[animationNames]].<br>
<br>
Class names listed in CfgVehicles [[Model Config#AnimationSources|AnimationSources]] bound to "Proxy" controller can also be animated with [[animate]] command (see [[createVehicle/vehicles]]).

<template lineStart="1"><title>Feature arma3</title><part><name index="1"/><value> It is recommended that [[animateSource]] command is used instead of [[animate]] whenever is possible, as it is more efficient and optimised for MP</value></part></template>

<template lineStart="1"><title>warning </title><part><name index="1"/><value> Mixing [[animateSource]] command with [[animate]] command to animate the same part may produce some undefined behaviour</value></part></template> </value></part><part><name>DESCRIPTION</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="4"/><value> objectName [[animate]] [animationName, phase, speed] </value></part><part><name>SYNTAX</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>p1</name>=<value> objectName: [[Object]] </value></part><part><name>PARAMETER1</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>p2</name>=<value> [animationName, phase, speed]: [[Array]] </value></part><part><name>PARAMETER2</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>p3</name>=<value> animationName: [[String]] - name of the animation. This is the class-name of the animation defined in the config. </value></part><part><name>PARAMETER3</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>p4</name>=<value> phase: [[Number]] - range 0 (start point of the animation) to 1 (end point of the animation). The speed, in which the animation is processed, is defined in the addon's config.cpp and cannot be changed during running missions. </value></part><part><name>PARAMETER4</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>p5</name>=<value> speed: [[Boolean]] or [[Number]] - When [[true]] animation is instant. Since <template><title>arma3</title></template> v1.65.138459 [[Number]] > 0 is treated as config speed value multiplier </value></part><part><name>PARAMETER5</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name index="5"/><value> [[Nothing]] </value></part><part><name>RETURNVALUE</name>=<value>

____________________________________________________________________________________________
		  
</value></part><part><name>x1</name>=<value> <code>_building [[animate]] ["maindoor", 1];</code> </value></part><part><name>EXAMPLE1</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>x2</name>=<value> <code>_building [[animate]] ["Door_1_rot", 1, [[true]]];</code> </value></part><part><name>EXAMPLE2</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>x3</name>=<value> Create Offroad and add flashing police light bar:<code>offroad = "C_Offroad_01_F" [[createVehicle]] ([[player]] [[getRelPos]] [5, 0]);
offroad [[animate]] ["HidePolice", 0];
offroad [[animate]] ["BeaconsStart", 1];</code> </value></part><part><name>EXAMPLE3</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="6"/><value> [[animationPhase]], [[setFaceAnimation]], [[animateSource]], [[animationSourcePhase]], [[animateDoor]], [[doorPhase]], [[animationNames]] </value></part><part><name>SEEALSO</name>=<value>

</value></part></template>

<h3 style="display:none">Notes</h3>
<dl class="command_description">
<comment><!-- Note Section BEGIN -->
</comment><dd class="notedate">Posted on Aug 2007
<dt class="note">[[User:Mikero|Mikero]]
<dd class="note">Animations can be used on existing game models such as houses that have doors eg. The general syntax is<code>house [[animate]] ["dvere1", 1]</code>to 'open' the door and house animate ["dvere1",0] to 'close it'. Whether used on Oem addons, or official ones, an internal working knowledge (via config.cpp) of the model's animated name(s) is required.<br>
<br>
'open' and 'close' are visual perceptions of the state of the model, and are a design decision of the p3d. Open does not, necessarily mean, 1, and close does not mean 0. <br>
'0' and '1' are better seen as FULLY_OFF and FULLY_ON<br>
If a door is initially closed in the model, FULLY_ON, will open it. If it is initialy OPEN visually, in the model, FULLY_ON will close it.<br>
<br>
<tt>initphase = 1;</tt> (in config cpp) does not alter open and close meanings, all it does is set the model to the 'on' (rather than 'off') state to begin with. Whether on means open or close visually is a p3d design decision.

<dd class="notedate">Posted on  June 2011
<dt class="note">[[User:Tyger|Tyger]]
<dd class="note">Also, to animate the object called "Bar Gate" in ArmA, use the following: <code>myGate [[animate]] ["Bargate",1]</code> to close it, and <code>myGate [[animate]] ["Bargate", 0]</code> to open it.
<comment><!-- Note Section END -->
</comment></dl>

</comment><dl class="command_description">
<dd class="notedate">Posted on February 16, 2016 - 21:33 (UTC)</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:RageBone|RageBone]]</dt>
<dd class="note">
"Bargate" was exchanged with "Door_1_rot" at one point:
<code>object [[animate]] ["Bargate", 0]; <template><title>cc</title><part><name index="1"/><value>doesn't work</value></part></template></code>
<code>object [[animate]] ["Door_1_rot", 0]; <template><title>cc</title><part><name index="1"/><value>works</value></part></template></code>
</dd>
</dl>

<dl class="command_description">
<dd class="notedate">Posted on March 14, 2016 - 00:34 (UTC)</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:Killzone Kid|Killzone Kid]]</dt>
<dd class="note">
To animate bargate use [[animateSource]]:
<code>bargate [[animateSource]] ["Door_1_source", 1];</code>
</dd>
</dl>

<dl class="command_description">
<dd class="notedate">Posted on November 25, 2017 - 20:55 (UTC)</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:SteveStevenson|SteveStevenson]]</dt>
<dd class="note">

For pop-up targets, you can keep the target down (until you tell it to pop up) with:
<code>target1 [[animate]] ["terc", 1];</code>

When you're ready for the target to pop up, you can use:
<code>target1 [[animate]] ["terc", 0];</code>

With this setting, the target will return to its usual behavior of going down when hit and automatically popping back up again. To make the target stay down after being hit, add the following line:
<code>target1 [[addEventHandler]] ["HitPart", { target1 [[animate]] ["terc", 1]; }];</code>

</dd>
</dl>
